com.tiemens.secretshare.engine

Class SecretShare

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.tiemens.secretshare.engine.SecretShare

  • public class SecretShare
extends java.lang.Object
    Main class for the "Shamir's Secret Sharing" implementation. General description: A secret is divided into "n" pieces of data, such that "k" of those pieces can be used to reconstruct the secret, but "k-1" of those pieces gets you nothing. The polynomials generated will be order "k-1", e.g. if k=3, then f(x) = secret + a*x^1 + b*x^2 and there will be "k" of those polynomials, each with random [and discarded] coefficients 'a', 'b', etc.

    • Method Detail

      • createAppropriateModulusForSecret

        public static java.math.BigInteger createAppropriateModulusForSecret(java.math.BigInteger secret)
        http://www.cromwell-intl.com/security/crypto/diffie-hellman.html says "... choosing some prime p which is larger than the largest possible secret key". Sadly, "larger" is not enough for this implementation [for an unknown reason]. Some test data shows: for a secret with 103 bits, 115 is not enough 116 is enough for a secret with 159 bits, 160 is enough So - this method provides guidance on the modulus to use for a given secret.
        Parameters:
        secret - number
        Returns:
        a modulus that (should) work in this library. It may be larger than it needs to be, but it will work.

      • createRandomModulusForSecret

        public static java.math.BigInteger createRandomModulusForSecret(java.math.BigInteger secret)
        NOTE: you should prefer createAppropriateModulusForSecret() over this method.
        Parameters:
        secret - as biginteger
        Returns:
        prime modulus big enough for secret

      • createRandomModulusForSecret

                                                java.util.Random random)
        NOTE: you should prefer createAppropriateModulusForSecret() over this method.
        Parameters:
        secret - as biginteger
        random - you provide the random
        Returns:
        prime modulus big enough for secret*
